1.1.4.12	COMPLIANCE AUDITS
Programs are evaluated annually; audited at least every three years through PSM compliance audits; and weekly safety inspections of the facility are conducted by cross functional teams. Action items resulting from these are tracked to a timely completion. The PSM Policy includes a description of how the Compliance Audit element is implemented in HSES0931.

1.1.5	FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
Within the last five years, there have been no accidental releases of regulated substances that resulted in onsite injuries, death, or property damage, or any offsite impacts.

1.1.6	EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The facility will continue to conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the local Indianapolis Fire Department and Marion County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). As appropriate, also involved in emergency response for the facility would be the local Indianapolis Police Department, State Police, and other coordinating agencies and local hospitals.

The Indianapolis  Health, Safety, Security & Environmental Manager and the Senior Safety Specialist are responsible for coordinating the emergency actions. A written and specific Emergency Response Plan for the facility is in place and that plan has been coordinated with local officials. The Emergency Response Program provides the essential planning for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.

1.1.4.5	TRAINING
A training program has been established to ensure that personnel are well trained in the specific duties of their jobs (the process also includes an annual Training Needs Analysis). The PSM Policy includes a description of how the Training element is implemented in HSES0460.

1.1.4.6	CONTRACTOR SAFETY PROGRAM
It is HCC's objective to partner with contractors that share the same safety philosophy. A dedicated, collective, and consistent approach by HCC and contractors will enhance and maintain the safety and health of our respective employees. The PSM Contractor Management Program element is included in HSES0857.

1.1.4.7	PRE-START-UP SAFETY REVIEWS
A prestart-up safety review walk down and checklist is completed for changes that impact the Process Safety Information. HSES0302 Pre-Startup Safety Review includes a description of how the Prestart-up Safety Review element is implemented.

1.1.4.8	MECHANICAL INTEGRITY
An equipment inspection program is in place to ensure equipment remains in good condition to prevent releases. The PSM includes a description of how the Mechanical Integrity element is implemented in MNTS0146.

1.1.4.9	SAFE WORK PROCEDURES
A work permit system is in place to ensure that work on process equipment and hot work are conducted in a safe manner. The PSM Policy includes a description of how the Hot Work element is implemented in HSES0363.

1.1.4.10	MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE
A management of change system has been established and implemented to ensure that changes are thoroughly reviewed prior to implementation. HSES0302 Management of Change Procedure includes a description of how the Management of Change element is implemented.

Part of this program has also involved identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases. A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include:
	Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in power supply to the process control system by having a backup power generator.
	Preventive maintenance and testing of vessels through the Mechanical Integrity program helps to ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
	Minimizing the possibility of a release of hydrogen with shutdown interlocks installed on process equipment.
	Reducing the risk of overfilling by having level alarms and/or indicators on the storage tank.
	Implementing operating procedures for unloading and transfer operations.

In addition, the following specific prevention programs are in place:

1.1.4.1 EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION
It is the policy of HCC to seek participation of employees at all levels in establishing procedures and practices that govern Health, Safety and Environmental issues.  The PSM Policy includes a description of how the Employee Participation element is implemented in HSEL0038.

1.1.4.2 PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION
Process safety information is maintained for the facility. The PSM Policy includes a description of how the Process Safety Information element is implemented in HSEL0039.

1.1.4.3	PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS (PHA) AND OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Detailed process hazard assessments, using HAZOP, are conducted on the facility to ensure that it has been designed safely. The PSM policy includes a description of how the Process Hazard Analysis element is implemented in HSES1148.

Hydrogen, a flammable gas, is the only EPA RMP regulated substance used at the facility in amounts greater than the threshold quantity, therefore the facility is subject to the EPA Risk Management Program regulation, 49 CFR Part 68. Other flammable liquids collected, processed and/or produced at the refinery have a flashpoint above 73° F (22.8° C) and a boiling point below 100° F (37.8° C). In order to meet the EPA definition for a flammable liquid, the flammable liquid must be a NFPA Class 1A flammable liquid; Any liquid or gaseous material that is liquid while under pressure and has a flashpoint below 73° F (22.8° C) and a boiling point below 100° F (37.8° C) (i.e., Class 1A flammable liquids). Thus, other flammable liquids do not meet the definition of a covered substance.

The facility is regulated under the Program Level 3 requirements as it is subject to OSHA PSM.

1.1.3 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by HCC.  These high standards include:
	Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
	Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases 
are minimized.
	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
	Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.

1.1.1  INTRODUCTION AND POLICIES
HCC is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors, and the public while fully complying with applicable laws and regulations. HCCs management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of its Health, Safety, Security and Environmental Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 

The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility and planned changes to improve safety at the plant.

1.1.2 STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Indianapolis Refinery (or the re-refinery), operated by HCC, is a re-refinery with the capacity to process 85 million gallons of used oil annually. The lubricant base oil produced is distributed by tank transport and rail cars to a variety of end users or finished oil blenders across North America. These Group II base oils are well suited to formulate a wide variety of automotive, industrial, and marine lubricants as well as diluents for additives and process oil applications.

Storage capacity at the refinery totals nearly 6,300,000 gallons with approximately 2,016,000 gallons dedicated to used oil storage and nearly 1,680,000 gallons for HCC 150 lubricant base oil. Additional storage on site includes 50,400 gallons for HCC 80 lubricant base oil and over 1,092,000 gallons for the storage of fuel and asphalt extender which are re-refinery by-products.
